title: Fell-continuous selections and topologically well-orderable spaces II

title_detail.value: Fell-continuous selections and topologically well-orderable spaces II

summary:
The present paper improves a result of V. Gutev and T. Nogura (1999) showing
that a space $X$ is topologically well-orderable if and only if there exists a
selection for $\mathcal{F}_2(X)$ which is continuous with respect to the Fell
topology on $\mathcal{F}_2(X)$. In particular, this implies that
$\mathcal{F}(X)$ has a Fell-continuous selection if and only if
$\mathcal{F}_2(X)$ has a Fell-continuous selection.

FELL-CONTINUOUS SELECTIONS AND TOPOLOGICALLY
WELL-ORDERABLE SPACES II
VALENTIN GUTEV
Abstract. The present paper improves a result of [3] by showing that
a space X is topologically well-orderable if and only if there exists a
selection for F2 (X) which is continuous with respect to the Fell topology
on F2 (X). In particular, this implies that F(X) has a Fell-continuous
selection if and only if F2 (X) has a Fell-continuous selection.

1. Introduction
Let X be a topological space, and let F(X) be the family of all non-empty
closed subsets of X. Also, let τ be a topology on F(X) and D ⊂ F(X). A
map f : D → X is a selection for D if f (S) ∈ S for every S ∈ D. A map
f : D → X is a τ -continuous selection for D if it is a selection for D which
is continuous with respect to the relative topology τ on D as a subspace of
F(X).
Two topologies on F(X) will play the most important role in this paper.
The first one is the Vietoris topology τV which is generated by all collections

Recently, the topologically well-orderable spaces were characterized in [3,
Theorem 1.3] by means of Fell-continuous selections for their hyperspaces of
non-empty closed subsets.
Theorem 1.1 ([3]). A Hausdorff space X is topologically well-orderable if
and only if F(X) has a τF -continuous selection.
In the present paper, we improve Theorem 1.1 by showing that one may
use τF -continuous selections only for the subset F2 (X) = {S ∈ F(X) : |S| ≤
2} of F(X). Namely, the following theorem will be proven.
Theorem 1.2. A Hausdorff space X is topologically well-orderable if and
only if F2 (X) has a τF -continuous selection.
About related results for Vietoris-continuous selections, the interested
reader is referred to van Mill and Wattel [6].
Theorem 1.2 is interesting also from another point of view. According to
Theorem 1.1, it implies the following result which may have an independent
interest.
Corollary 1.3. If X is a Hausdorff space, then F(X) has a τF -continuous
selection if and only if F2 (X) has a τF -continuous selection.
A word should be said also about the proof of Theorem 1.2. In general,
it is based on the proof of Theorem 1.1 stated in [3], and is separated in
a few different steps which are natural generalizations of the corresponding
ones given in [3]. In fact, the paper demonstrates that all statements of [3]
remain true if F(X) is replaced by F2 (X). Related to this, the interested
reader may consult an alternative proof of Theorem 1.2 given in [1] and
based again on the scheme in [3].
2. A reduction to locally compact spaces
In the sequel, all spaces are assumed to be at least Hausdorff.

Theorem 2.1. Let X be a space such that F2 (X) has a τF -continuous
selection. Then X is locally compact.

3. A reduction to compact spaces
For a locally compact space X we will use αX to denote the one point
compactification of X. For a non-compact locally compact X let us agree
to denote by α the point of the singleton αX \ X.
In what follows, to every family D ⊂ F(X) we associate a family α(D) ⊂
F(αX) defined by
α(D) = {S ∈ F(αX) : S ∩ X ∈ D ∪ {∅}}.
The following extension theorem was actually proven in [3, Theorem 3.1].
Theorem 3.1. Let X be a locally compact non-compact space X, and D ⊂
F(X). Then, D has a τF -continuous selection if and only if α(D) has a
τV -continuous selection g such that g −1 (α) = {{α}}.
Proof. Just the same proof as in [3, Theorem 3.1] works. Namely, if f is a
τF -continuous selection for D, we may define a selection g for α(D) by g(S) =
f (S ∩ X) if S ∩ X 6= ∅ and g(S) = α otherwise, where S ∈ α(D). Clearly
g−1 (α) = {{α}} and, as shown in [3, Theorem 3.1], g is τV -continuous. If
now g is a τV -continuous selection for α(D), with g−1 (α) = {{α}}, then
g(S ∪ {α}) ∈ S for every S ∈ D, so we may define a selection f for D by
f (S) = g (S ∪ {α}), S ∈ D. The verification that f is τF -continuous was
done in [3, Theorem 3.1].

4. Special selections and connected sets
In what follows, to every selection f : F2 (X) → X we associate an orderlike relation "≺f " on X (see Michael [5]) defined for x 6= y by
x1 ≺f x2 iff f ({x1 , x2 }) = x1 .
Further, we will need also the following ≺f -intervals:
(x, +∞)≺f = {z ∈ X : x ≺f z}
and
[x, +∞)≺f = {z ∈ X : x f z}.
Now, we provide the generalization of [3, Theorem 4.1] for the case of F2 (X).
Theorem 4.1. Let X be a space, a ∈ X, and let A ∈ F(X) be a connected
set such that |A| > 1 and a ∈ A ∩ X \ A. Also, let f : F2 (X) → X be a
τV -continuous selection for F2 (X). Then, f −1 (a) 6= {{a}}.
Proof. Suppose, on the contrary, that f −1 (a) = {{a}}. By hypothesis, there
exists a point b ∈ A, with b 6= a. Since f is τV -continuous, f ({a, b}) = b and
a ∈ X \ A, we can find a point c ∈ X \ A such that f ({b, c}) = b. Then,
B = A ∩ (c, +∞)≺f is a clopen subset of A because B = A ∩ [c, +∞)≺f , see
[5]. However, this is impossible because b ∈ A \ B, while a ∈ B.

5. A further result about special selections
Following [3], we shall say that a point a ∈ X is a partition of X if there
are open subset L, R ⊂ X \ {a} such that L ∩ R = {a} and L ∩ R = ∅.
We finalize the preparation for the proof of Theorem 1.2 with the following result about special Vietoris continuous selections and partitions which
generalizes [3, Theorem 5.1].
Theorem 5.1. Let X be a compact space, f a τV -continuous selection for
F2 (X), and let a ∈ X be a partition of X such that f −1 (a) = {{a}}. Then,
X is first countable at a.
Proof. By definition, there are open sets L, R ⊂ X \ {a} such that L ∩ R =
{a} and L ∩ R = ∅. Hence, both L and R are non-empty. Take a point
l0 ∈ L. Then, by hypothesis, f ({l0 , a}) = l0 . Since f is τV -continuous, this
implies the existence of a neighbourhood L0 ⊂ L of l0 and a neighbourhood
V0 of a such that
L0 ∩ V0 = ∅ and f (h{L0 , V0 }i ∩ F2 (X)) ⊂ L0 .
Since a ∈ R, there exists a point r0 ∈ V0 ∩ R. Observe that f ({a, r0 }) =
r0 ∈ V0 . Hence, just like before, we may find a neighbourhood R0 ⊂ R ∩ V0
of r0 and a neighbourhood W0 ⊂ V0 of a such that
R0 ∩ W0 = ∅ and f (h{R0 , W0 }i ∩ F2 (X)) ⊂ R0 .

Since X is compact, {ln : n < ω} has a cluster point l, and {rn : n < ω}
has a cluster point r. We claim that l = r. Indeed, suppose for instance
that l ≺f r (the case r ≺f l is symmetric). Then, there are disjoint open
sets Ul and Ur such that l ∈ Ul , r ∈ Ur , and x ≺f y for every x ∈ Ul
and y ∈ Ur , see [4]. Next, take ln ∈ Ul and rm ∈ Ur such that n >
m. Then, we have ln ≺f rm . However, by (3), (4) and (5), we get that
{rm , ln } ∈ h{Rm , Wm }i ∩ F2 (X), and therefore f ({rm , ln }) = rm . This is
clearly impossible, so l = r.
Having already established this, let us observe that b = l = r implies
b ∈ L ∩ R because l ∈ L and r ∈ R. However, L ∩ R = {a} which finally
implies that b = a.
We are now ready to prove that, for instance, {Wn : n < ω} is a local
base at a. To this end, suppose if possible that this fails. Hence, there
exists an open neighbourhood U of a such that Wn \ U 6= ∅ for every n < ω.
Next, whenever n < ω, take a point tn ∈ Wn \ U . Since X is compact,
{tn : n < ω} has a cluster point t 6∈ U . Then, t ≺f a and, as before,
we may find disjoint open sets Ut and Ua such that t ∈ Ut , a ∈ Ua , and

such that n > m. Then, tn ≺f rm , while, by (4) and (5), rm ≺f tn because

6. Proof of Theorem 1.2
In case X is a topologically well-orderable space, we may use Theorem
1.1.
Suppose that F2 (X) has a τF -continuous selection. If X is compact, then
Theorem 1.2 is, in fact, a result of van Mill and Wattel [6]. Let X be noncompact. By Theorem 2.1, X is locally compact. Then, by Theorem 3.1,

VALENTIN GUTEV

F2 (αX) has a τV -continuous selection f such that f −1 (α) = {{α}}. Relying
once again on the result of [6], αX is a linear ordered topological space with
respect to some linear order "<" on αX. It now suffices to show that there
exists a compatible (with the topology of αX) linear order "≺" on αX such
that α is either the first or the last element of αX, see [2, Lemma 4.1]. We
show this following precisely the proof of Theorem 1.1 in [3]. Namely, let
L = {x ∈ αX : x < α} and R = {x ∈ αX : α < x}.
Note that L, R ⊂ αX \ {α} = X are open subsets of αX. In case one of
these sets is also closed, the desired linear order "≺" on αX can be defined
by exchanging the places of L and R. Namely, by letting for x, y ∈ αX that
x ≺ y if and only if
x, y ∈ L and x < y, or
x, y ∈ R and x < y, or
x ∈ R and y ∈ L.
Finally, let us consider the case L ∩ R = {α}. Then, α is a partition of
αX. Hence, by Theorem 5.1, αX is first countable at α. Let C[α] be the
connected component of α in αX. Since f −1 (α) = {{α}}, it now follows
from Theorem 4.1 that C[α] = {α}. Indeed, C ′ = C[α] ∩ {x ∈ αX : x ≤ α}
and C ′′ = C[α] ∩ {x ∈ αX : x ≥ α} are both connected subsets of X with
α ∈ C ′ ∩ (X \ C ′ ) and α ∈ C ′′ ∩ (X \ C ′′ ) (consider that X \ C ′ ⊃ R and
X \ C ′′ ⊃ L), so that C ′ = {α} and C ′′ = {α}, whence also C[α] = {α}.
Then, αX has a clopen base at α. Indeed, let l ∈ L and r ∈ R. Since C[α]
is also the quasi-component of the point α, there are clopen neighbourhoods
Ul , Ur of α such that l 6∈ Ul and r 6∈ Ur . Then,
U = {x ∈ Ul ∩ Ur : l < x < r} = {x ∈ Ul ∩ Ur : l ≤ x ≤ r}
is a clopen neighbourhood of α with U ⊂ {x ∈ X : l < x < r}.
That is, αX has a clopen base at α and it is first countable at this point.
Then, let {Un : n < ω} be a decreasing clopen base at α, with U0 =
αX. Next, for every point x ∈ X, let n(x) = max{n : x ∈ Un } and, for
convenience, n(α) = ω. Finally, we may define a linear order "≺" on αX by
putting x ≺ y if and only if
either n(x) < n(y) or n(x) = n(y) and x < y.
Since {Un : n < ω} is a decreasing clopen base at α, the order "≺" is
compatible with the topology of αX. It is clear that, with respect to "≺",
α is the last element of X. This completes the proof.
